This class helped me develop the skills to approach literature rigorously and attentively. I learned to think about the mechanisms of narrative and storytelling, especially in relation to the salient themes or experienced affect of the book. I think I read all books, in and out of class, differently now.

The course provides a diverse and thought provoking selection of Japanese literature after 1970, which itself was a new and educational area for me to read from. Furthermore, the literature gave complexity and breadth to my image of modern Japan as a society, and how certain stereotypes, ways of thinking, and modes of living may not always be true. I definitely developed more analytical lenses for studying literature in general, and more vocabulary and fluency with engaging with the texts. I also enjoyed getting to become more familiar with larger ideas and movements in literature in general through supplementary literary study readings as well as the teachers own insight, such as postmodernism, biotropes, neoliberalism, etc.

I really appreciated the supplementary material that contextualized the literature we read; along with Professor Poland's lectures and our discussions, these really helped me situate the works and their themes within larger systems and histories. I also appreciated Professor Poland's attention to how students were feeling and what we wanted to discusshe was always accommodating while also making sure we developed cohesive, substantive conversations.

The syllabus was very strong; the progression backwards in time through a diverse and well-paced variety of works and supplementary readings felt well-thought out and effective. Because most of the works were assigned over the weekend, there was time to really engage with each text and then return each week with new ideas. Although the discussions in class moved freely and were overall interesting, I would have preferred if the professor had provided more structured, engaging, and even controversial questions that brought up the level of the class more. For example, although less related to the themes of the literature itself, one of our most engaging discussions was a spontaneous ranking of the works on a scale (like Dead Poets Society) of different metrics.

Absolutely! I came into the class not particularly familiar with Japanese lit, but knowing that I wanted to take a literature course. I think regardless of your interest in specifically Japanese literature, this was a great class for anybody who likes to read, and wants to become more attentive readers. I learned to think more critically and seriously about literature beyond the plot, and I truly think the skills I developed will stay with me long after college.
